hints_html:
What are the critical numbers of \(f\)? What are the intervals of increase/decrease of \(f\)? How do these relate to the extrema of \(f\)?

What are the intervals of concavity of \(f\)? What is an inflection point, and how does it relate to concavity?

It may be useful to find the x-intercept(s) of \(\displaystyle f\). In addition, note the behaviour of \(\displaystyle f'\) near \(x = 0\).
hints_latex:
What are the \textbf{critical numbers} of $f$? What are the intervals of
\textbf{increase/decrease} of $f$? How do these relate to the
\emph{extrema} of $f$?

What are the intervals of \textbf{concavity} of $f$? What is an
\textbf{inflection point}, and how does it relate to \emph{concavity}?

It may be useful to find the \emph{x}-intercept(s) of $\displaystyle f$.
In addition, note the behaviour of $\displaystyle f'$ near $x = 0$.
hints_raw:
What are the '''critical numbers''' of <math>f</math>? What are the intervals of '''increase/decrease'''  of <math>f</math>? How do these relate to the ''extrema'' of <math>f</math>?
What are the intervals of '''concavity''' of <math>f</math>? What is an '''inflection point''', and how does it relate to ''concavity''?
It may be useful to find the ''x''-intercept(s) of <math>\displaystyle f</math>. In addition, note the behaviour of <math>\displaystyle f'</math> near <math>x = 0</math>.
question: 8 (d)
sols_html:
From parts (a), (b), and (c) we know the following about \(f(x) = 63x^{2/7}-14x^{9/7}\):

  • The critical numbers of \(f\) (where \(f'\) is zero or does not exist) are \(\displaystyle x = 0, 1\)

  • \(f\) is increasing on \(x \in (0,1)\) and decreasing on \(x \in (-\infty,0) \cup (1, \infty)\)

  • \(f\) has a local minimum at \(\displaystyle x = 0\) and a local maximum at \(\displaystyle x = 1\) (note the change in the increase/decrease of \(f\))

  • \(f\) is concave up on \(x \in (-\infty,-\tfrac{5}{2})\) and concave down on \(x \in (-\tfrac{5}{2},0) \cup (0, \infty)\)

  • \(f\) has an inflection point (changes concavity) at \(x = -\tfrac{5}{2}\)

  • \(\displaystyle f(x) = x^{\frac{2}{7}} (63 - 14x)\) and thus \(f\) has x-intercepts at \(x = 0, \tfrac{9}{2}\)

  • \(\lim_{x \to 0^-} f'(x) = -\infty\) and \(\lim_{x \to 0^+} f'(x) = \infty\), thus the graph of \(f\) is very steep near \(x = 0\)

Plotting the points of interest gives the following:

Accounting for increase and decrease gives the following rough sketch:

Finally, incorporating concavity leads us to the final graph:
sols_latex:
From parts
{(a)},
{(b)},
and
{(c)}
we know the following about $f(x) = 63x^{2/7}-14x^{9/7}$:

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  The \textbf{critical numbers} of $f$ (where $f'$ is zero or does not
  exist) are $\displaystyle x = 0, 1$
\item
  $f$ is \textbf{increasing} on $x \in (0,1)$ and \textbf{decreasing} on
  $x \in (-\infty,0) \cup (1, \infty)$
\item
  $f$ has a \textbf{local minimum} at $\displaystyle x = 0$ and a
  \textbf{local maximum} at $\displaystyle x = 1$ (note the change in
  the increase/decrease of $f$)
\item
  $f$ is \textbf{concave up} on $x \in (-\infty,-\tfrac{5}{2})$ and
  \textbf{concave down} on $x \in (-\tfrac{5}{2},0) \cup (0, \infty)$
\item
  $f$ has an \textbf{inflection point} (changes concavity) at
  $x = -\tfrac{5}{2}$
\end{itemize}

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  $\displaystyle f(x) = x^{\frac{2}{7}} (63 - 14x)$ and thus $f$ has
  \emph{x}-intercepts at $x = 0, \tfrac{9}{2}$
\end{itemize}

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  $\lim_{x \to 0^-} f'(x) = -\infty$ and
  $\lim_{x \to 0^+} f'(x) = \infty$, thus the graph of $f$ is very steep
  near $x = 0$
\end{itemize}

Plotting the points of interest gives the following:

\includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{../json_data/MATH100/December_2013/Math_100_December_2013_Question_8(d)_Step_1.png}

Accounting for increase and decrease gives the following rough sketch:

\includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{../json_data/MATH100/December_2013/Math_100_December_2013_Question_8(d)_Step_2.png}

Finally, incorporating concavity leads us to the final graph:

\includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{../json_data/MATH100/December_2013/Math_100_December_2013_Question_8(d)_Step_3.png}
sols_raw:
From parts [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH100/December_2013/Question_08_(a)|(a)]], [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH100/December_2013/Question_08_(b)|(b)]], and [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH100/December_2013/Question_08_(c)|(c)]] we know the following about <math>f(x) = 63x^{2/7}-14x^{9/7}</math>:

* The '''critical numbers''' of <math>f</math>  (where <math>f'</math> is zero or does not exist)  are <math>\displaystyle x = 0, 1</math>
* <math>f</math> is '''increasing''' on <math>x \in (0,1)</math> and '''decreasing''' on <math>x \in (-\infty,0) \cup (1, \infty)</math>
* <math>f</math> has a '''local minimum''' at <math>\displaystyle x = 0</math> and a '''local maximum''' at <math>\displaystyle x = 1</math> (note the change in the increase/decrease of <math>f</math>)
* <math>f</math> is '''concave up''' on <math>x \in (-\infty,-\tfrac{5}{2})</math> and '''concave down''' on <math>x \in (-\tfrac{5}{2},0) \cup (0, \infty)</math>
* <math>f</math> has an '''inflection point''' (changes concavity) at <math>x = -\tfrac{5}{2}</math>


* <math>\displaystyle f(x) = x^{\frac{2}{7}} (63 - 14x)</math> and thus <math>f</math> has ''x''-intercepts at <math>x = 0, \tfrac{9}{2}</math>


* <math>\lim_{x \to 0^-} f'(x) = -\infty</math> and <math>\lim_{x \to 0^+} f'(x) = \infty</math>, thus the graph of <math>f</math> is very steep near <math>x = 0</math>


Plotting the points of interest gives the following:

[[File:Math 100 December 2013 Question 8(d) Step 1.png|600px|center]]


Accounting for increase and decrease gives the following rough sketch:

[[File:Math 100 December 2013 Question 8(d) Step 2.png|600px|center]]


Finally, incorporating concavity leads us to the final graph:

[[File:Math 100 December 2013 Question 8(d) Step 3.png|600px|thumbnail|center|<math>\displaystyle f(x) = 63x^{2/7}-14x^{9/7}</math>]]
statement_html: Let \(\displaystyle y = f(x) = 63x^{2/7}-14x^{9/7}\). Sketch the graph of \(\displaystyle y=f(x)\) and indicate the inflection point(s) on your graph. (The results from parts (a), (b), and (c) may be useful.)

Let $\displaystyle y = f(x) = 63x^{2/7}-14x^{9/7}$. Sketch the graph of
$\displaystyle y=f(x)$ and indicate the inflection point(s) on your
graph. (The results from parts
{(a)},
{(b)},
and
{(c)}
may be useful.)
